channel.title: Reading policy | Intermediate Public & Nonprofit Financial Management

item.title: Communicating Findings
item.description:
Required

  • Chapter 14 in Practical Research Methods for Nonprofit and Public Administrators1

  1. Elizabeth O’Sullivan, Gary R. Rassel, and Jocelyn DeVance Taliaferro, Practical Research Methods for Nonprofit and Public Administrators (New York, NY: Routledge, 2010).↩︎

item.title: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) and Simple Regression
item.description:
Required

  • Chapter 13 in Essential Statistics for Public Managers and Policy Analysts.1 This is available on Blackboard.

  1. Evan M. Berman and XiaoHu Wang, Essential Statistics for Public Managers and Policy Analysts, 4th ed. (Thousand Oaks, CA: CQ Press, 2018).↩︎

item.title: How to Test the Difference between Two Groups
item.description:
Required

  • Chapter 13 in Applied Statistics for Public and Nonprofit Administration1

  1. Kenneth J. Meier, Jeffrey L. Brudney, and John Bohte, Applied Statistics for Public and Nonprofit Administration, 9th ed. (Stamford, CT: Cengage, 2015).↩︎

item.title: Performance Dashboard in Governments
item.description:
Required

  • Chapter 1 in Presenting Data Effectively.1 This is available on Blackboard.

  1. Stephanie D. H. Evergreen, Presenting Data Effectively: Communicating Your Findings for Maximum Impact, 2nd ed. (Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications, 2018).↩︎

item.title: Understand the Process of Generalizing from a Random Sample to the Population from which it is drawn
item.description:
Required

  • Chapter 9 in Practical Research Methods for Nonprofit and Public Administrators1
  • Chapter 11 in Essential Statistics for Public Managers and Policy Analysts.2 This is available on Blackboard.

Additional pre-class assignment

Choose a social program that you’re interested in. Draw a logic model or results chain that is as detailed as you can get it, including all the inputs, activities, outputs, and outcomes you can think of. This doesn’t have to be perfect—we’ll talk about it and critique and improve it in class.

You can do this by hand or with something like Draw.io, Lucidchart, or Creately.

  1. Elizabeth O’Sullivan, Gary R. Rassel, and Jocelyn DeVance Taliaferro, Practical Research Methods for Nonprofit and Public Administrators (New York, NY: Routledge, 2010).↩︎

  2. Evan M. Berman and XiaoHu Wang, Essential Statistics for Public Managers and Policy Analysts, 4th ed. (Thousand Oaks, CA: CQ Press, 2018).↩︎

item.title: How to Describe the Relationships between Two or More Variables
item.description:
Required

  • Chapter 8 (pg 129-131) in Practical Research Methods for Nonprofit and Public Administrators1

  1. Elizabeth O’Sullivan, Gary R. Rassel, and Jocelyn DeVance Taliaferro, Practical Research Methods for Nonprofit and Public Administrators (New York, NY: Routledge, 2010).↩︎

item.title: How to Effectively Describe Statistics in Both Graphical and Numerical Form
item.description:
Required

  • The syllabus and assignments pages for this class
  • Chapter 5 in Practical Research Methods for Nonprofit and Public Administrators1

  1. Elizabeth O’Sullivan, Gary R. Rassel, and Jocelyn DeVance Taliaferro, Practical Research Methods for Nonprofit and Public Administrators (New York, NY: Routledge, 2010).↩︎
